newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: New Zealand's FEC chair rejects capital gains tax.
newsitem.headline: New Zealand's FEC chair rejects capital gains tax.

text.p: The chairman of parliament's powerful finance and expenditure select committee, Tony Ryall, on Wednesday rejected a capital gains tax for New Zealand.
Reserve Bank Governor Don Brash said at a meeting of the committee on Wednesday that the absence of a capital gains tax in New Zealand was an anomaly.
Brash said a zero tax on asset appreciation was one of the factors encouraging speculative investments such as housing.
"Dr Brash's idea is going nowhere rapidly," Ryall said later in a statement.
He said in every other country where there was a capital gains tax there was still property speculation.
"These sort of taxes are full of loopholes. We want a government that reduces taxes, not increases them," Ryall said.
